name: (2Z)-[(4-chlorophenyl)hydrazono](4-phenyl-1,3-thiazol-2-yl)ethanenitrile
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-987
Reason: The compound in question is a complex structure, which includes an array of functional groups that contribute to its melting point. The base structure to consider here is the thiazole ring, which when unsubstituted has an estimated melting point in the range of around 120 degrees Celsius (observed in compounds with similar structural features). The functional groups and their expected contributions are estimated as follows: - Chlorophenyl group: Due to increased molecular weight and additional van der Waals forces, the chlorophenyl is likely to add approximately +20 degrees to the melting point. - Phenyl group: Similar to the chlorophenyl group, this should also contribute to an increase in melting point due to its impact on molecular weight and van der Waals forces, this could also be estimated at around +20 degrees. - Hydrazono linkage: The presence of this group may enhance the rigidity of the molecule, possibly contributing around +10 degrees. - Nitrile group: The cyano group is highly polar and can participate in dipole-dipole interactions, which can further increase the melting point by about +5 degrees. Summing up the contributions: Thiazole base: 120 degrees Chlorophenyl group: +20 degrees Phenyl group: +20 degrees Hydrazono linkage: +10 degrees Nitrile group: +5 degrees This leads to an estimated total increase of 55 degrees over the base thiazole structure's melting point.
Test (Predicted reason):
The compound in question has several functional groups that influence its melting point. The base structure is a thiazole, which has a melting point of around 100°C. The presence of a phenyl group typically increases the melting point due to increased molecular weight and pi-pi interactions; this can be estimated to add around +20°C. The hydrazone group is known to form strong intermolecular hydrogen bonds, which can significantly raise the melting point; this effect can be estimated to add around +30°C. The chlorophenyl group introduces both electron-withdrawing character and increased molecular weight, which can further increase the melting point; this effect can be estimated to add around +20°C. The nitrile group is polar and can participate in dipole-dipole interactions, which can contribute to an increase in the melting point; this effect can be estimated to add around +10°C. Adding these values gives a cumulative adjustment of +70°C relative to the base structure of the thiazole.
##Prediction: 170.0
